body: created https://github.com/apache/activemq/pull/158 against master, closing this one then
Sorry about this, it was meant to be opened only against our fork for now.
You guys are doing openwire over HTTP? why not send the PR upsstream? :)
We will send it upstream, but first, we need to go through the legal process, fix backward compatibility with old XStream serialisation and prepare a PR against master (currently it's 5.9.0).

Generally a good practice to include the JIRA issue data in your PRs.  If you include a reference to the JIRA issue (AMQ-6189) the PR is related to the tooling will add a comment in the JIRA so that people can see where this comes from.
I didn't know there was a JIRA issue for this, I just thought I'd PR a fix :)
Please open a Jira Issue for this at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AMQ

BTW, I didn't create a JIRA for this due to its trivialness.  If you want, I can create a JIRA and append the ticket.

Hi @johnament,

Sorry we didn't get to this earlier.  We try to ensure that the merge commit is always done by someone other than the author as a first line of defence against bugs.  However, there have been cases in the past where the author has merged commits with trivial changes such as this.  If you have a PR outstanding for a while, the best thing to do is just to comment on the PR and include one of the Artemis guys, myself, Clebert or Justin.  

I don't think we need a JIRA for this.  I'll merge it.  

Thanks
@johnament Oops I read this as an Artemis JIRA.  I realise the process we try to use is slightly different.
Any comments on this?
Please close this
This was a trivial one. Thank you for the correction.
@wgqazll what is the purpose of this PR? It looks like it was submitted by accident and should not be merged.
Hi @priyankpande9, activemq-4.0 is no longer actively maintained by the community and so the PR you propose makes little sense.

So the question I'd have is what is really being solved here?  From the context it looks like the hangs you are trying to fix relate to a client sending a command that requires a response at its root, even though the one you are targeting is RemoveInfo (ShutdownInfo never requires a response so a client would never hang on that).  However RemoveInfo isn't the only command that expects a response and so a client might still hang due to the code in question if for some reason the act of the broker eventually breaking the socket on close didn't kick it out of whatever stall it is in.  

It seems like a better strategy might be to just formulate a response to any incoming command that needs one if the state of the broker is stopping when the command arrives, and pass only responses when one is generated even if the broker isStopping is true.  Whether or not you returned an ErrorResponse for everything when isStopping is true is one thing to think about, do you want the client to just assume things worked or do you want it to be able to report an error indicating that the broker is stopping.

As for the change you've made so far, if you were to go with that I don't know if the array based search approach is necessary vs just adding a 'isRemoveInfo' to Command to go along with 'isShutdownInfo' and just doing an plain old 'if (command.isRemoveInfo() || command.isShutdownInfo()) to that code path.

@tabish121 good questions, I'll try to answer one by one.
1. What is being solved? Three things: one is the timeout for responses not received, second is the BrokerStoppedException which I don't think should be thrown in this case (TransportConnection.java:202), but most importantly third is that I am looking at this and other shutdown issues in an effort to bring down the unit tests time and make them more consistent.
2. Better strategy. Agree, I was looking at a minimally invasive change, but I like more what you propose. Will look into it. Comments like yours are the reason why I created this PR in the first place. Thanks.
3. The array piece. That's actually the way I had it (except I used getDataStructureType() instead of isRemoveInfo()). The two solutions are somewhat equivalent, except to add another command, in the array solution you would just add it to the array, in the other case you'd add another clause to the if. I am personally not a fan of the if/then/else overuse.

I'll take a shot at the better strategy you suggested. More elegant and correct.

This is not a change that could be made for a few reasons. One would be that the master deviated too much from the 5.11 branch, which is no longer actively maintained by the community. @sundarmr , could you please close this PR?

the documented names probably make more sense given they have the most context into what is being configured, unfortunately the code is expecting the stripped down options.  Changing it now would indeed break existing users.  Perhaps addition of methods that match the documented values while retaining the older ones is an option

Yeah we could add new methods and mark the old ones as deprecated and they can use the new methods.

I like the one with the graph :)

I like the feather. it leverages the apache brand... it's simpler...

The graph is nice as well, but I personally liked the feather...


Martyn showed me a draft mixing the feather and a little graph around it.. I liked that one as well (not part of this commit).

I did try to get the graph and feather to work together, but it just didn't look right.  The feather was meant to be a nod to the original logo.  I was trying to create something modern, but also recognisable as the existing ActiveMQ brand.  Visually, my order of preference is graph, plain, feather.  

I do also like the modern orange and black circle submission by @michaelandrepearce.
The bit I like about the graph is it symbolises connectivity which is exactly what activemq is all about
I see no tests to validate, and you'd need to create a JIRA issue to cover this case.
I agree with @michaelandrepearce , I am a fan of the graph logo for the same reasons stated.
